newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan to ship nuclear waste to North Korea - TV.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan to ship nuclear waste to North Korea - TV.

text.p: Taiwan has signed a contract with North Korea to ship 60,000 barrels of the island's nuclear waste to the communist state, a Taipei television station reported on Sunday.
The contract had been signed by state utility Taiwan Power Co and North Korea on Saturday, state-funded Taiwan Television Enterprise reported.
It said the agreement followed Taiwan's failure to reach a similar deal with the Marshall Islands and Russia.
The contract-signing was given a very low profile for fear of environmental protests, the broadcast said. It gave no other details.
Taiwan decided in July 1996 to stop sending nuclear waste to its tiny Lanyu island, Taiwan's only nuclear waste dump, following strong protests by aboriginals there.
Since 1982, Taiwan has stored 97,672 barrels of nuclear waste at the Lanyu dump, close to its absolute capacity of 98,112 barrels, according to official figures.
Taiwan Power has promised to remove all the nuclear waste in Lanyu by 2002 and it has been seeking sites overseas.
The state utility offered in August to pay 3.2 billion Taiwan dollars ($116 million) to local governments and residents in Taiwan if they could offer a dump for the nuclear waste.
Taiwan currently has three nuclear power plants and the government plans to build a fourth in the northern county of Taipei.
